title: House Day 32 for the 2025 Session
summary:
Overview:
The Georgia House session on this day featured the introduction and consideration of several bills, including HB 743, HB 744, HB 745, HB 746, HB 884, SB 145, and SB 88. The session began with a scripture reading and prayer by the guest chaplain, Pastor Powell Goodhard from Sherwood Baptist Church in Albany.

Key Actions:
**HB 743**: [Bill description]
**HB 744**: [Bill description] 
**HB 745**: [Bill description]
**HB 746**: [Bill description]
**HB 884**: [Bill description]
**SB 145**: [Bill description]
**SB 88**: [Bill description]

Bills Introduced (First Reading):
- [Bill 1]: [Description]
- [Bill 2]: [Description]
- [Bill 3]: [Description]

Notable Moments:
- Pastor Powell Goodhard delivered the opening prayer and spoke about the importance of wisdom from the Book of Proverbs for the legislators.

Votes:
- HB 743 was opposed by some members but ultimately passed.
- SB 145 was passed unanimously.

Attendance:
- The Speaker called all members to the floor and conducted a roll call to ensure a quorum was present.

Adjournment:
The session was adjourned. The next session will be held on [Date].

All members will please come to the floor. All members. Our our convening having arrived. All members will please come to the floor and take their seats. Mr. Clerk will you ring the bell? All members please come to the floor. We were given just to many for regulated industries to get over here. All members please come to the floor. We're going to have the afternoon row call. All members present will please vote green to signify their presence in the chamber. And Mr. Clerk will you unlock the machines? All members voted. All members vote. Now I believe all members have voted. So Mr. Clerk you will lock the machines. Well good afternoon. Good to see you all after a couple days off and a great St. Patrick's Day celebrated down in Savannah and in Dublin and some other places around the state. Hope you all were able to enjoy all the good times. The St. Patrick's Day brings. But we got some business to do today. So we're going to get started. Doorkeeper, please close the doors and keep them closed. As is our custom, we will begin our day with Scripture reading and prayer by our chaplain, after which we will pledge allegiance to the flag of our country. Our chaplain this afternoon be introduced by the gentleman from the 150 second House District. Representative Bill Yerter, Representative Yerter. Thank you Mr. Speaker. It's my pleasure to have Pastor Powell Goodhard from Sherwood Baptist Church in Albany. Powell has been married to Brebel for almost 29 years and they have two daughters, Shana and Kaylee. And they were not able to be with us today but Powell brought one of his members, Chad Wolvenson. Chad also serves on the City Commission down in Albany and glad to have Chad with us today. Pastor Powell received his BA from the University of Georgia, his Masters of Divinity from South Eastern Baptist Theological Seminary, and his PhD from Adonai University. He was the founding and lead pastor of Life Baptist Church in Las Vegas, Nevada. He's also published three books. Powell has been the senior pastor at Sherwood Baptist Church in Albany since 2021. Sherwood is commonly known as a church. It started the movie. Sherwood movie for me. They produce movies facing the Giants, Fireproof, Courageous, War Room, and most recently the Forge. These are inspirational movies that people have seen all over the world. Sherwood really does and Powell does a wonderful job, registering to the Albany Air and spreading the gospel to those folks. Powell, welcome to the people's house. Thank you, Representative Yerda, for the introduction and also speaker burns for the invitation. Distined ladies and gentlemen and members of the Georgia House of Representatives, it is an absolute honor to be with you all this afternoon. I want to thank you all for not only what you do but for the people you serve and how you go about serving the people in the state of Georgia. Now in your role I am gathering there is not a lack of people offering their opinions and bringing complaints and many times making demands. And as a Baptist pastor I can 100% connect with that entire idea. So anyway, many times people do not understand the way to responsibility that you all are shouldering each and every day. And the types of decisions that you are making that are going to impact thousands of people within your district as well as millions of people around the state of Georgia. And I want to thank you for your willingness to serve the people in the state. So as I was thinking about our time together I wanted there to be something that I could share that would be of value to you, to the role that you are in, to the responsibilities that you carry as well as to the decisions that you make. And very quickly the idea of the book of Proverbs came to mind. The book of Proverbs is a book of wisdom and wisdom is more than knowledge. Wisdom is the right application of knowledge. Wisdom is what allows a person to live a skillful life that they do the right thing at the right time. And in fact the very first four verses of Proverbs chapter 1 Solomon tells us the purpose behind the Proverbs. And here's what those verses say. These are the Proverbs of Solomon, David's son, King of Israel. Their purpose is to teach people wisdom and discipline to help them understand the insights of the wise. Their purpose is to teach people to live disciplined and successful lives, to help them do what is right, just and fair. These Proverbs will give insight to the simple knowledge and discernment to the young people. For the person who is willing to study the Proverbs and to apply the teachings that they will find, there are three different sets of benefits that Solomon describes to those who will study and apply these. The Proverbs will teach wisdom and discipline that enables a person to live a structured and successful life. Everybody wants to be competent and effective and successful in what they do. And Solomon is saying if you'll apply these, that's exactly what will happen. Also the Proverbs help a person gain understanding so that they will do what is right and what is just and what is fair. Wisdom leads to right actions and just living and fair treatment. It really doesn't matter what person you're talking to, what political party they're a part of, what religious affiliation they might have, or even personal worldview they might have. Those are values that many of us hold in common. The Proverbs also will give insight, knowledge, and discernment to those who are young or inexperienced. Just a connection piece here, I was 27 years old when I became a senior pastor. And I'm not exactly sure who thought that was a great idea, me for accepting the position or the church for offering the position, but at that point in my life, I thought I knew a pretty good amount about a lot of things. Over the course of the years, I have realized how little I actually knew at that point in my life. I needed insight and knowledge and discernment. And here's the thing, it doesn't matter how old we are right now. Our world has changed so fast we are always walking into challenges that there has not been a forerunner going into. We need wisdom and insight and discernment. So 26 years ago, I had a mentor come and challenge me to read the Proverbs, the chapter in the Book of Proverbs that corresponds with the date of the month. There's typically 31 days in the month, there's 31 chapters in the Book of Proverbs. And that was a challenge I took to heart, 26 years ago. It takes about five minutes a day, but here's what I can tell you. Five minutes a day, you will find a little bit of wisdom will make a huge impact in your life. There are countless times that what I read in the Book of Proverbs that day helped me not make an unwise decision. There are days I didn't know what to do, and Proverbs 35 and 6 would remind me, trust in the Lord with all of your heart. Do not lean on your own understanding. See his will in all you do, and he will show you which path to take. I didn't think I needed anybody's help to make the decision I was about to make, and yet at the same time Proverbs 12-15 challenged me. Fools think their own way is right, but the wise listen to others. There are some days that people would say some really hurtful things, and I wanted to respond and like fashion back to them. I read the Proverb of the day, and it says in Proverbs 12-16, a fool is quick-tempered, but a wise person stays calm when insulted. A little wisdom goes a long way. When we seek God, seek His will, God has a way of getting the right word at the right time to help us make the right decision. Many times the question is not, can I do it? The question is, is it wise? I encourage you, take that Proverbs challenge every single day. Five minutes of time can pay off in a huge way. A little bit of wisdom goes a long way. If you would stand with me as we have a word of prayer. Heavenly Father, we thank You so much for this group, for who is represented, for the decisions that are being made, for the laws, the pieces that are being passed God. We ask You are blessing upon every part of it. May You give wisdom, discernment, and insight that will impact not only the families and individual districts, but also those throughout the state of Georgia. We thank You for what You will do in Jesus' name. Amen. If You would, as pledge allegiance. We thank You for the pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America and to the Republic for which it stands. One nation under God, indivisible with liberty and justice. Thank you. That was awesome. Members, we want to thank Brother Paul for that devotion. I will congratulate this house. You do listen a lot and you exhibit great wisdom and decisions we make. Representative Gamble is recognized to present the bill. The gentleman is recognized. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Senate Bill 276 brings Georgia into compliance with federal requirements. The U.S. Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2022 requires states to have laws in effect that bar-level third-party payers from refusing payment to Medicaid for a service-based solely on the fact that prior authorization was not issued for the bill. This bill is being brought to us from the agency DCH has requested this in order to be in compliance with federal law. As you know, Medicaid is the payer of last resort and only pays for covered services if there are no other liable third-party payers. This could be a commercial insurance plan, a lawsuit settlement, or workers compensation settlement. This bill will ensure that those primary payment sources cannot unreasonably deny payment to Medicaid for services for which they are responsible. This bill will uphold the integrity of the Medicaid program and increase the revenue to the program as payment by primary sources are unable to be denied based on a requirement for prior authorization. Senate Bill 109 by Senator Harper, sin of the 15th to be entitled to act to amend chapter 25 in Title 33, the fiscal code of Georgia and attended relating to life insurance so as to prohibit a policy of group life insurance from excluding or restricting liability for certain deaths occurring while an individual's on active duty. Thank you, Mr. Speaker, members of the House. I bring to you Senate Bill 109. This is the same as House Bill 182 that was passed unanimously by this body on February 24th. This is a Department of Insurance Bill that deals with group life insurance as it pertains to members of our armed forces. Every life insurance policy contains exclusions. An exclusion is a defined cause of death that is not covered by the terms of the policy and is clearly stated in the language of the policy. In most policies, the term active war is most often used to define this exclusion, however, in a group life policy, the term active duty is used. Now, a person can be on active duty and not be in a war zone. In fact, only about 5% of our military actually see combat. So the purpose of the language of this bill is to make it clear that simply being on active duty in and of itself is not a valid reason to deny claim. Mr. Speaker, that's the bill. I'll stand for any questions. The gentleman has a couple of questions to your left. Representative Heffner has recognized for a question. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Does the gentleman yield? I do. The term active duty can apply to whether you're actually engaged in some function of your job or whether you're off duty. The term active duty is a broad umbrella that applies in a lot of ways. And with an insurance policy, the exclusions that I'm referring to particularly in this sense, active war is generally the one that we're talking about as being the issue that is of concern because you can be in an accident while being on active duty.
